Background.data_info: For those with talent being high (B=1), the probability of income level being low (D=0) is 0.7995. The probability of income level being low (D=0) is 0.6448. The probability of talent being low (B=0) and income level being low (D=0) is 0.4144.

Questions.Instruction: Consider the probability of sufficiency (PS) of talent on income level.
Questions.Question: Given that talent was low and income level was low, what is the lower bound of the probability that income level would have been high if the talent had been high?

Reason.Step 1:
Calculate P(D=0|do(B=1))
P(D=0|do(B=1))=P(D=0|B=1)=0.7995

Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 4 nodes A, B, C, D, and 3 edges A->B, B->C, B->D.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents temperature, B represents talent, C represents blood pressure and D represents income level.
Background.data_info: For those with talent being high (B=1), the probability of income level being high (D=1) is 0.2005. The probability of talent being low (B=0) and income level being low (D=0) is 0.4144. The probability of talent being high (B=1) and income level being high (D=1) is 0.0578.

Questions.Instruction: Consider the probability of sufficiency (PS) of talent on income level.
Questions.Question: Given that talent was low and income level was low, what is the upper bound of the probability that income level would have been high if the talent had been high?

Reason.Step 1:
Calculate P(D=1|do(B=1))
P(D=1|do(B=1))=P(D=1|B=1)=0.2005
